Quiz Results

In today\'s business environment which of the following trends are making SRM more important? \n1) Evolving from input methodologies to outcome thinking\n2) An increasing need for a compliance focused function within the procurement division

interactions.lmstext: In today\'s business environment which of the following trends are making SRM more important? \n1) Evolving from input methodologies to outcome thinking\n2) An increasing need for a compliance focused function within the procurement division

choices.lmstext: Only 1 is true
Only 2 is true
Both 1 and 2 are true
Neither 1 or 2 are true

slides.title: SRM is substantially about? 1) Supporting the transactions of the procurement department 2) Delivering enhanced industry expertise to the business\n3) Supporting the creation of value in trading relationships\n4) Delivering insights to strategic

interactions.lmstext: SRM is substantially about? 1) Supporting the transactions of the procurement department 2) Delivering enhanced industry expertise to the business\n3) Supporting the creation of value in trading relationships\n4) Delivering insights to strategic

slides.title: Which of the options below is a compelling method of demonstrating a \'customer of choice\' mentality for strategic suppliers?\n

interactions.lmstext: Which of the options below is a compelling method of demonstrating a \'customer of choice\' mentality for strategic suppliers?\n

choices.lmstext: Requesting a \'most favored customer\' pricing status from our suppliers
Aligning the right talent to the relationship
Highlighting the faults of our competitors
Demanding our suppliers\' best ideas and initiatives to give us competitive advantage

slides.title: We need close, collaborative relationships based on creativity and innovation with:\n

interactions.lmstext: We need close, collaborative relationships based on creativity and innovation with:\n

choices.lmstext: The biggest suppliers
The suppliers which are most strategic to our future
The suppliers with the highest volume of Purchase Orders
The commodity suppliers

slides.title: How is SRM defined in this program?\n

interactions.lmstext: How is SRM defined in this program?\n

choices.lmstext: The function that seeks to develop collaborative relationships across all suppliers for the delivery of significant tangible business benefits for both parties
The function that seeks to develop long-term relationships with potential suppliers for the delivery of long term solutions to long term problems
The function that builds a holistic approach across the contract lifecycle to deliver additional value beyond the confines of the contract
The function that is responsible for identifying, vetting and providing governance for supplier relationships across the business, for better value for the purchaser

slides.title: Implementing best practice in SRM will help us to:\n

interactions.lmstext: Implementing best practice in SRM will help us to:\n

choices.lmstext: Deliver value more sustainably compared to traditional procurement approaches
Manage our contracts better across our entire supply chain
Improve our performance management capability
Obtain deeper supplier discounts through our supply chain and across our delivery partners

slides.title: SRM\'s primary purpose is all about maximizing delivery of additional value for:\n

interactions.lmstext: SRM\'s primary purpose is all about maximizing delivery of additional value for:\n

choices.lmstext: Our own organization
The supplier\'s organization
Our shareholders
Ourselves and our key suppliers

slides.title: According to World Commerce & Contracting, what is the number 1 purpose of a contract?\n

interactions.lmstext: According to World Commerce & Contracting, what is the number 1 purpose of a contract?\n

choices.lmstext: The contract is primarily an outward demonstration of our brand and corporate values
A contract is entered into to generate economic benefit for both parties
A contract is primarily a formal record of rights, responsibilities and obligations
A contract is a focus for risk management

slides.title: World Commerce & Contracting research has identified the average value erosion in our contract relationships to be?\n

interactions.lmstext: World Commerce & Contracting research has identified the average value erosion in our contract relationships to be?\n

slides.title: Research suggests that for many in procurement, managing supplier relationships means:\n

interactions.lmstext: Research suggests that for many in procurement, managing supplier relationships means:\n

choices.lmstext: Finding opportunities to expand value in relationships
Driving improving relationship quality
Control of the supplier and whole life cost reductions
Building creativity and innovation

slides.title: Why do we need to focus on strategic supplier relationships in today\'s business context?  1) We need to demonstrate our curiosity, candidness and commitment to being a customer of choice\r2) There is increasing opportunity in our traditional\n

interactions.lmstext: Why do we need to focus on strategic supplier relationships in today\'s business context?  1) We need to demonstrate our curiosity, candidness and commitment to being a customer of choice\r2) There is increasing opportunity in our traditional\n

choices.lmstext: Only 1 is true
Only 2 is true
Both 1 & 2 are true
Neither 1 or 2 is true

slides.title: Which of the below is the most fundamental question that should be asked when embarking upon a SRM program:\n

interactions.lmstext: Which of the below is the most fundamental question that should be asked when embarking upon a SRM program:\n

choices.lmstext: Do we have commitment from top levels of management?
What is the duration of our SRM program?
What budget has been committed to the SRM program?
How many suppliers are we going to manage?

slides.title: Why is it important to segment relationships across your supply base?

interactions.lmstext: Why is it important to segment relationships across your supply base?

choices.lmstext: It allows you to increase your purchasing power
You can drive efficiencies in your procurement process through better category management
It helps to align allocation of resources against the goals of the relationship
It is in fact not important; all suppliers need to be managed

slides.title: What is the most appropriate approach to dealing with suppliers of routine, transactional style purchases?

interactions.lmstext: What is the most appropriate approach to dealing with suppliers of routine, transactional style purchases?

choices.lmstext: Form collaborative relationships and implement a regular communication schedule
Seek innovation from the suppliers
Adopt a commodity approach and drive hard for the best price
Invite them into supplier councils

slides.title: Which of the following is most likely a key consideration when designing an approach to supplier segmentation?

interactions.lmstext: Which of the following is most likely a key consideration when designing an approach to supplier segmentation?

choices.lmstext: How many product lines are we purchasing from the supplier?
What contract type are we most likely to implement?
What is our competition doing?
What is the likely roadmap for the supplier relationship?

slides.title: In Peter Kraljic\'s Purchasing Portfolio Matrix from 1983, a bottleneck supplier would be best characterized as a supplier where there is:

interactions.lmstext: In Peter Kraljic\'s Purchasing Portfolio Matrix from 1983, a bottleneck supplier would be best characterized as a supplier where there is:

choices.lmstext: High spend and high risk but your supplier has the majority of the power
Higher risk and lower spend, where you should aim to mitigate or eliminate the risk
High spend where you have the power in the relationship
Low spend and low risk where your aim is to achieve efficiency

slides.title: Which of the following statements describes a segmentation method traditionally used to differentiate between suppliers where relationship management principles were not used?

interactions.lmstext: Which of the following statements describes a segmentation method traditionally used to differentiate between suppliers where relationship management principles were not used?

choices.lmstext: Evaluating the innovation and added value that each supplier delivers
Evaluating the criticality of the relationship to both your company and the supplier
Evaluating statistically the delivery performance of your supplier
Evaluating the relationship\'s alignment to your business strategy

slides.title: Which of the following are evaluation criteria that could be used to determine the strategic supply base? 1) The need to protect the delivery of your services and a supplier\'s criticality in that goal2) Supplier spend

interactions.lmstext: Which of the following are evaluation criteria that could be used to determine the strategic supply base? 1) The need to protect the delivery of your services and a supplier\'s criticality in that goal2) Supplier spend

choices.lmstext: Only 1 is true
Only 2 is true
Both 1 & 2 are true
Neither 1 nor 2 is true

slides.title: As we increase our focus on collaboration and innovation, then we are more likely to achieve:

interactions.lmstext: As we increase our focus on collaboration and innovation, then we are more likely to achieve:

choices.lmstext: Sustained cost reductions
Cost efficiency
Innovation for growth
Ability to deliver our contracts on budget

slides.title: Where a supplier has a singular relationship to the tier above and below them, they would be best categorized as being in a:

interactions.lmstext: Where a supplier has a singular relationship to the tier above and below them, they would be best categorized as being in a:

choices.lmstext: SRM program
Supply network
Supply chain
Supply ecosystem

slides.title: A heavily contract focused approach to supply management is a characteristic of which of the following?

interactions.lmstext: A heavily contract focused approach to supply management is a characteristic of which of the following?

choices.lmstext: An SRM program
A supply network
A traditional supply chain
A supplier ecosystem

slides.title: A supplier ecosystem can be best described as one where:\n1) There is greater equality of visibility between the players in the ecosystem\n2) Rewards, risk and control flow down the system

interactions.lmstext: A supplier ecosystem can be best described as one where:\n1) There is greater equality of visibility between the players in the ecosystem\n2) Rewards, risk and control flow down the system

choices.lmstext: Only 1 is true
Only 2 is true
Both 1 & 2 are true
Neither 1 or 2 is true

slides.title: In the referenced McKinsey study, a business shock that lasts at least one month, if not longer would occur on average every:

interactions.lmstext: In the referenced McKinsey study, a business shock that lasts at least one month, if not longer would occur on average every:

choices.lmstext: 2.7 years
3.2 years
3.7 years
4.2 years

slides.title: Porter\'s 5 forces include which of the following? 1) Threat of new entrants\r2) Threat of substitutes 3) Threat of longevity\r4) Intensity of competitive rivalry

interactions.lmstext: Porter\'s 5 forces include which of the following? 1) Threat of new entrants\r2) Threat of substitutes 3) Threat of longevity\r4) Intensity of competitive rivalry

slides.title: In the world of SRM, a stakeholder is someone who is: \n1) External to your organization but not a supplier\n2) Internal to your organization

interactions.lmstext: In the world of SRM, a stakeholder is someone who is: \n1) External to your organization but not a supplier\n2) Internal to your organization

choices.lmstext: Only 1 is true
Only 2 is true
Both 1 & 2 are true
Neither 1 or 2 is true

slides.title: What are the three \'Ps\' that make for excellent stakeholder management?

interactions.lmstext: What are the three \'Ps\' that make for excellent stakeholder management?

choices.lmstext: Power, potential impact and position
Presumption, power and plain speaking
Prominence, position and people
Prayer, people and politeness

slides.title: For really effective stakeholder management, you should ensure that:

interactions.lmstext: For really effective stakeholder management, you should ensure that:

choices.lmstext: You understand who influences your stakeholder groups
Your stakeholders maintain a dignified level of independence from the SRM team
You advise stakeholders to always look for the commercial benefit for your organization
All stakeholders are kept adequately informed of the activities of the SRM team

slides.title: Effective communication can be best described as:

interactions.lmstext: Effective communication can be best described as:

choices.lmstext: Informing others of your position
Making sure that messages are delivered to an audience
A two way activity
Making sure actions are carried out as and when required

slides.title: Evaluating the success of a communications activity helps us to:

interactions.lmstext: Evaluating the success of a communications activity helps us to:

choices.lmstext: Congratulate ourselves on a job well done
Let us know whether we have achieved our objectives
Know that our communications activity is now complete
Close down the communication exercise and get on with delivering relationship value

slides.title: As part of defining the objectives of a communication plan we should:

interactions.lmstext: As part of defining the objectives of a communication plan we should:

choices.lmstext: Use existing corporate communications principles and avoid any changes
Eliminate any uncommon communication channels
Not consider the competitive landscape that we and our suppliers operate within
Understand the impact of the communications method we choose

slides.title: There are many outcomes of using a virtual communication methodology. These include: 1) Perception of increased sincerity 2) Loss of value opportunities\n3) Greater chance of negotiation breakdown\n4) Enhanced likelihood of anger and retribution

interactions.lmstext: There are many outcomes of using a virtual communication methodology. These include: 1) Perception of increased sincerity 2) Loss of value opportunities\n3) Greater chance of negotiation breakdown\n4) Enhanced likelihood of anger and retribution

slides.title: With an SRM program in place, customers may be seen to: \n1) Be easier to do business with \n2) Create new markets and opportunity

interactions.lmstext: With an SRM program in place, customers may be seen to: \n1) Be easier to do business with \n2) Create new markets and opportunity

choices.lmstext: Only 1 is true
Only 2 is true
Both 1 & 2 are true
Neither 1 or 2 is true

slides.title: A supplier who sees your company as being in their growth category is most likely going to:

interactions.lmstext: A supplier who sees your company as being in their growth category is most likely going to:

choices.lmstext: Provide their A team and a continuous improvement mentality
Deliver the minimum for the maximum gain
Provide you with better than average support to deliver opportunity into your account
Be passive in their approach as they are unafraid as yet  of losing you

slides.title: Benchmarking is primarily about:

interactions.lmstext: Benchmarking is primarily about:

choices.lmstext: Ascertaining whether the prices we are getting from our suppliers are fair
Defining where we are at, at a given point in time
Identifying which business processes, if overhauled, will give the greatest economic benefit
Confirming that we are better than our competitors

slides.title: One desired outcome of an SRM benchmark is about:

interactions.lmstext: One desired outcome of an SRM benchmark is about:

choices.lmstext: Confirmation that our concerns and reasons for performing the exercise were justified
Being able to say "I told you so"
Inspire new ideas
Being able to drive down price

slides.title: According to WorldCC research, which contract terms are most important in supporting the delivery of value?\n1) Scope and goals 2) Responsibilities of the parties\n3) Data privacy 4) Price and price changes

interactions.lmstext: According to WorldCC research, which contract terms are most important in supporting the delivery of value?\n1) Scope and goals 2) Responsibilities of the parties\n3) Data privacy 4) Price and price changes

slides.title: According to WorldCC research, which contract terms focusing on risk allocation are the most frequently negotiated?\n1) Limitation of liability 2) Indemnification\n3) Price and price changes 4) Performance guarantees

interactions.lmstext: According to WorldCC research, which contract terms focusing on risk allocation are the most frequently negotiated?\n1) Limitation of liability 2) Indemnification\n3) Price and price changes 4) Performance guarantees

slides.title: A single source supplier where there would be a high cost to exit the relationship would be best described as what type of supplier?

interactions.lmstext: A single source supplier where there would be a high cost to exit the relationship would be best described as what type of supplier?

choices.lmstext: Strategic
Developing suppliers
Legacy
Commodity

slides.title: When considering the personal attributes of an SRM Manager, developing what is a key attribute for an SRM manager? \n1) Trust\n2) Openness

interactions.lmstext: When considering the personal attributes of an SRM Manager, developing what is a key attribute for an SRM manager? \n1) Trust\n2) Openness

choices.lmstext: Only 1 is true
Only 2 is true
Both 1 & 2 are true
Neither 1 or 2 is true

slides.title: When looking at a situation, a good SRM manager:

interactions.lmstext: When looking at a situation, a good SRM manager:

choices.lmstext: Can predict how things will turn out and therefore controls the outcome
Unconsciously moves towards their natural competence
Understands that the other side\'s view or perspective is the only one that matters regardless
Openly communicates the vision for the direction of the relationship

slides.title: A good SRM manager aims to:

interactions.lmstext: A good SRM manager aims to:

choices.lmstext: Be transparent in their actions
Create alignment between their personal goals and the opposition\'s
Depend simply on logic to prevail
Evaluate emotionally what the meaning of every deal is

slides.title: The SRM manager\'s role is primarily:

interactions.lmstext: The SRM manager\'s role is primarily:

choices.lmstext: A highly bureaucratic endeavor
Filled with red tape and administration
About operational efficiency
About leadership and influencing desired behaviors

slides.title: When an SRM program is in place, what is a supplier\'s value proposition?

interactions.lmstext: When an SRM program is in place, what is a supplier\'s value proposition?

choices.lmstext: The market capitalization of the supplier
The amount of money that they can save your company
The amount of money that they can help your company to make
Evaluation of how their objectives and their expectations align with yours

slides.title: According to a Manchester Consulting survey of executives around trust builders and busters, which of the following is the top ways in which trust is eroded?

interactions.lmstext: According to a Manchester Consulting survey of executives around trust builders and busters, which of the following is the top ways in which trust is eroded?

choices.lmstext: Inconsistency between what we say and what we do
Betraying confidences
Being of closed mind
Withholding information and lying or telling half-truths

slides.title: In his book the "Trust Equation", David Maister says that the element of trust called \'reliability\' is about:

interactions.lmstext: In his book the "Trust Equation", David Maister says that the element of trust called \'reliability\' is about:

choices.lmstext: Having the expertise to deliver the work
Being willing and able to give and receive feedback
Behaving consistently with declared beliefs and values
Considering one\'s own goals and desires

slides.title: An SRM Manager should understand their business at least as well as the supplier\'s Account Director because:

interactions.lmstext: An SRM Manager should understand their business at least as well as the supplier\'s Account Director because:

choices.lmstext: It helps the supplier to sell business solutions
The supplier may have many isolated relationships within your organization that they are unable to link together
SRM creates a balance of perspective, and reduces the advantage a supplier may have
It helps to define who you should next introduce to the Account Director

slides.title: In the relationship with a strategic supplier, how should an exit strategy be developed?

interactions.lmstext: In the relationship with a strategic supplier, how should an exit strategy be developed?

choices.lmstext: By your supplier and ratified by your organization
By your organization and ratified by the supplier
Jointly by both organizations
Once exit is instigated

slides.title:
Which of these must a relationship manager consider when planning an exit strategy? 
1) Does a contract exit schedule exist?  2) Does the supplier have an exit transition plan? 
3) A strategic relationship will always have a satisfactory exit.
4)

interactions.lmstext:
Which of these must a relationship manager consider when planning an exit strategy? 
1) Does a contract exit schedule exist?  2) Does the supplier have an exit transition plan? 
3) A strategic relationship will always have a satisfactory exit.
4)

slides.title: Which of the following occurrences might not lead to the conclusion of a contract with the need to implement an exit strategy?

interactions.lmstext: Which of the following occurrences might not lead to the conclusion of a contract with the need to implement an exit strategy?

choices.lmstext: The relationship terminates for convenience through lack of commercial viability
A contracted project has been completed and handed over successfully, with all monies agreed and paid
A lapsing contract can\'t be renewed because there is a regulatory requirement for re-tender
One party is subject to acquisition by another company

slides.title: If a supplier is being replaced by a direct competitor, it is important to exclude them as rapidly as possible:

interactions.lmstext: If a supplier is being replaced by a direct competitor, it is important to exclude them as rapidly as possible:

choices.lmstext: Yes, because they will be disruptive
Yes, because of exposures to confidential information
It depends on the overall situation
No, because there may be a need for collaboration and hand-over between the suppliers

slides.title: The rights of exit carry a cost, this could include: \n1) Reputational cost\n2) Retendering costs

interactions.lmstext: The rights of exit carry a cost, this could include: \n1) Reputational cost\n2) Retendering costs

choices.lmstext: Only 1 is true
Only 2 is true
Both 1 & 2 are true
Neither 1 or 2 is true

slides.title: What is the term for an organization that consistently receives preferential access to resources, ideas and innovations from its key suppliers that give it a competitive edge in its markets?

interactions.lmstext: What is the term for an organization that consistently receives preferential access to resources, ideas and innovations from its key suppliers that give it a competitive edge in its markets?

choices.lmstext: Innovative customer
Key account opener
Regional customer
Customer of choice

slides.title: A key role of the SRM manager is to:

interactions.lmstext: A key role of the SRM manager is to:

choices.lmstext: Leverage the supply network
Enforce the contract terms and conditions
Monitor service levels
Manage invoicing and payment

slides.title: In order to gain unrestricted access to stakeholders, the SRM manager needs to have:

interactions.lmstext: In order to gain unrestricted access to stakeholders, the SRM manager needs to have:

choices.lmstext: Empathy, communication, rapport building, resilience
Backing of senior management
A wide network of influential colleagues
A reputation as somebody who is not to be crossed

slides.title: In communications across cultures, a high context culture is likely to demonstrate:\n1) The ability to read between the lines\n2) Explicit and exact communication principles

interactions.lmstext: In communications across cultures, a high context culture is likely to demonstrate:\n1) The ability to read between the lines\n2) Explicit and exact communication principles

choices.lmstext: Only 1 is true
Only 2 is true
Both 1 & 2 are true
Neither 1 or 2 is true

slides.title: When communicating your SRM plan across your business, what is the first thing you should consider?

interactions.lmstext: When communicating your SRM plan across your business, what is the first thing you should consider?

choices.lmstext: How to minimize questions
That we all see the world in different ways
The attitudes of the audience
What are the capabilities required within SRM to deliver its contribution

slides.title: As an SRM manager, soft skills are important.  Which of these is not a soft skill?

interactions.lmstext: As an SRM manager, soft skills are important.  Which of these is not a soft skill?

choices.lmstext: Knowing your natural motivations
Knowing your emotional intelligence
Knowing your company\'s structure and strategy
Knowing your social style

slides.title: When thinking about the qualities of an SRM manager, a high IQ generally indicates that they have a high level of emotional intelligence:

interactions.lmstext: When thinking about the qualities of an SRM manager, a high IQ generally indicates that they have a high level of emotional intelligence:

choices.lmstext: No, a high IQ does not automatically indicate a high emotional intelligence capability
No, those with a low IQ will naturally develop a high emotional intelligence to compensate
Yes, a high IQ and a high emotional intelligence go hand in hand with each other
Yes, those with a high IQ understand how to develop their emotional skills

slides.title: The emotional skill that enables an SRM manager to stop their emotions interfering with tasks they are undertaking is called:

interactions.lmstext: The emotional skill that enables an SRM manager to stop their emotions interfering with tasks they are undertaking is called:

choices.lmstext: Self Regulation
Social Awareness
Empathy
Motivation

slides.title: When is it appropriate to take a benchmark? \n1) If we want to compare ourselves against our competitors \n2) When we want to confirm prices being charged by our suppliers are competitive

interactions.lmstext: When is it appropriate to take a benchmark? \n1) If we want to compare ourselves against our competitors \n2) When we want to confirm prices being charged by our suppliers are competitive

choices.lmstext: Only 1 is true
Only 2 is true
Both 1 & 2 are true
Neither 1 nor 2 is true

slides.title: From an SRM perspective, metrics are a starting point for:

interactions.lmstext: From an SRM perspective, metrics are a starting point for:

choices.lmstext: Contractual renegotiation
Internal political positioning
Determination of contractual liabilities and penalties
Informed dialog

slides.title: Key outcomes for a successful relationship in an SRM program, that are considered appropriate to measure include:

interactions.lmstext: Key outcomes for a successful relationship in an SRM program, that are considered appropriate to measure include:

choices.lmstext: The extent to which the supplier is engaging as an equal
The extent to which the supplier is refusing to supply to our competitors
The extent of the supplier\'s success with other organizations
The extent of the price cuts enjoyed by the customer

slides.title: Within an SRM Program, when is it inappropriate to take a benchmark?

interactions.lmstext: Within an SRM Program, when is it inappropriate to take a benchmark?

choices.lmstext: When we want to compare ourselves against external data
When we need an internal review of processes to see if improvements can be made
When a trigger event leads to a continuous improvement initiative
When we want to prove a point

slides.title: Which is a problem a supplier will suffer when there is no SRM is in place?  1) Having difficulty accessing everyone inside a customer they want to \n2) Having a disjointed approach to dealing with the customer

interactions.lmstext: Which is a problem a supplier will suffer when there is no SRM is in place?  1) Having difficulty accessing everyone inside a customer they want to \n2) Having a disjointed approach to dealing with the customer

choices.lmstext: Both 1 and 2 are true
Only 2 is true
Only 1 is true
Neither 1 nor 2 is true

slides.title: Which of the following are common problems for a supplier that may be solved through SRM?\n1) They do not understand how the company works  \n2) Finding ways to navigate the intricacies of the organization

interactions.lmstext: Which of the following are common problems for a supplier that may be solved through SRM?\n1) They do not understand how the company works  \n2) Finding ways to navigate the intricacies of the organization

choices.lmstext: 1) is correct
2) is correct
Both 1) and 2) are correct
Neither 1) nor 2) are correct

slides.title: In SRM we are aiming to drive an attitude where the supplier sees themselves as a \'Responsible Supplier\'.  What are the attributes that a responsible supplier will exhibit?

interactions.lmstext: In SRM we are aiming to drive an attitude where the supplier sees themselves as a \'Responsible Supplier\'.  What are the attributes that a responsible supplier will exhibit?

choices.lmstext: They suppress knowledge about how they can help customer company objectives
They will approach and ask for the opportunity to present their entire product portfolio
They will use the SRM program to help them evaluate opportunities
They will focus on pricing rather than relationship harmony

slides.title: Once an SRM program is in place, clarifying roles and responsibilities within a governance framework will be seen by a responsible supplier as what?

interactions.lmstext: Once an SRM program is in place, clarifying roles and responsibilities within a governance framework will be seen by a responsible supplier as what?

choices.lmstext: A way to maintain their value proposition
A way to avoid their responsibilities in the SRM program
An opportunity to shift risk back to the customer
An opportunity to create dependence upon their portfolio

slides.title: An SRM program should mainly focus on:

interactions.lmstext: An SRM program should mainly focus on:

choices.lmstext: Strategic suppliers
Commodity suppliers
Developing suppliers
Legacy suppliers

interactions.lmstext: Subjective measurement is a tool that is most suited to measuring the relationship with which type of supplier?

choices.lmstext: Commodity
Strategic
Legacy
Developing

slides.title: When writing a business case for SRM, an example of a defined goal of SRM is to:

interactions.lmstext: When writing a business case for SRM, an example of a defined goal of SRM is to:

choices.lmstext: Identify the number of suppliers your organization has

slides.title: Which statement best defines an example  where a supplier may not need to be included in an SRM program?

interactions.lmstext: Which statement best defines an example  where a supplier may not need to be included in an SRM program?

choices.lmstext: A focused and defined relationship already exists for a supplier delivering to a specific part of the business
There is internal conflict in prioritization of the supply chain
There is a lack of formalized governance
The relationship is dysfunctionally managed

slides.title: In considering the scope of your SRM program, knowledge of your internal customers for each supplier will allow you to: \n1) Understand the business drivers of different areas of your company\n2) Identify other areas where your supplier should have

interactions.lmstext: In considering the scope of your SRM program, knowledge of your internal customers for each supplier will allow you to: \n1) Understand the business drivers of different areas of your company\n2) Identify other areas where your supplier should have

Neither 1 nor 2 is true

slides.title: How we interpret our contractual rights can be different to how the other side views our rights, even in well constructed contracts:

interactions.lmstext: How we interpret our contractual rights can be different to how the other side views our rights, even in well constructed contracts:

choices.lmstext: No, contract managers understand and can interpret contact clauses in a common manner
Yes, differing interpretation is possible even in well constructed contracts
No, if the contract is well written there should be no room for differing interpretation
Yes, it is impossible for any contract to run smoothly

slides.title: In an SRM program, is it acceptable for you to request that a key supplier\'s account manager be replaced because you believe them to be acting solely in the interests of the supplier?

interactions.lmstext: In an SRM program, is it acceptable for you to request that a key supplier\'s account manager be replaced because you believe them to be acting solely in the interests of the supplier?

choices.lmstext: Yes, this is a legitimate step if you feel the relationship or contract is suffering
No, people issues should be resolved cordially, asking for people to be removed is wrong
Yes, personality clashes are difficult to overcome so this is the best course of action
No, people issues are inevitable so they should be expected and managed in accordance with the contract

slides.title: When we choose to manage our relationships with our suppliers in a segmented way:

interactions.lmstext: When we choose to manage our relationships with our suppliers in a segmented way:

choices.lmstext: We are making a coordinated investment in how we manage the supply chain
We are interested in a process oriented approach to supplier management
We are less concerned with managing company resources and more concerned about strategic goals
We are more concerned about our overall procurement strategy and less concerned about support for business units

slides.title: Things that are very likely to be considered when segmenting the supply chain, include:

interactions.lmstext: Things that are very likely to be considered when segmenting the supply chain, include:

choices.lmstext: Placing a maximum of 25% of our suppliers in any one segment
The average value of purchase orders raised
The dispute resolution process employed with each supplier
The total spend with each supplier

slides.title: In managing your supplier segmentation, once a supplier has been categorized, is it allowable to transfer them to a different segment at a later date?

interactions.lmstext: In managing your supplier segmentation, once a supplier has been categorized, is it allowable to transfer them to a different segment at a later date?

choices.lmstext: Yes, if their importance to us changes, they can be transitioned to a different segment
No, once categorized it is unethical to move a supplier into another segment because other suppliers may complain
Yes, if the supplier challenges their segmentation status it is possible to allocate them into their preferred segment
No, once categorized the segmentation task is done it is time to manage our business

slides.title: In selling the benefits of an SRM program, which of these is a benefit of being a \'customer of choice\'?

interactions.lmstext: In selling the benefits of an SRM program, which of these is a benefit of being a \'customer of choice\'?

choices.lmstext: Better levels of corporate hospitality
Favored pricing arrangements
Access to innovation earlier in the lifecycle
Having an eager supplier who wants to show you their entire capability set

slides.title: Of the following, who is the primary catalyst for creating engagement and development of the relationships with strategic suppliers?

interactions.lmstext: Of the following, who is the primary catalyst for creating engagement and development of the relationships with strategic suppliers?

choices.lmstext: The supplier\'s senior executives
Your stakeholders
Your senior executives
You, as the SRM Manager

slides.title: Within SRM, for relationships to excel there should be a:

interactions.lmstext: Within SRM, for relationships to excel there should be a:

choices.lmstext: Shared account plan
Balance of power in the favor of the SRM Manager
A signed contract
Rigorous benchmarking of price and quality

slides.title: When considering SRM governance requirements, the supplier should be sharing with us how they are looking to drive their revenues and other key measures, and how their team is targeted and rewarded, so that we can:

interactions.lmstext: When considering SRM governance requirements, the supplier should be sharing with us how they are looking to drive their revenues and other key measures, and how their team is targeted and rewarded, so that we can:

choices.lmstext: Ensure suppliers do not make excessive profits from the relationship
Negotiate better pricing in the relationship
Ensure we do not lose the advantage in negotiation
Understand motivations, drivers and how we can contribute to their success

slides.title: When designing an SRM governance structure that includes RACI, what is the maximum number of roles that can be defined as \'Accountable\' for each task or deliverable in a RACI matrix?

interactions.lmstext: When designing an SRM governance structure that includes RACI, what is the maximum number of roles that can be defined as \'Accountable\' for each task or deliverable in a RACI matrix?

choices.lmstext: Two
One
Several
Three

slides.title: A well written contract will act as an instrument for structured communication. What is the benefit of this?\n1) Better understanding of our requirements 2) Better adherence to governance\n3) Better allocation of risk 4) Removes the need for flexibility

interactions.lmstext: A well written contract will act as an instrument for structured communication. What is the benefit of this?\n1) Better understanding of our requirements 2) Better adherence to governance\n3) Better allocation of risk 4) Removes the need for flexibility

slides.title: It is becoming a matter of core competence for organizations to be able to:

interactions.lmstext: It is becoming a matter of core competence for organizations to be able to:

choices.lmstext: Attract and effectively manage the best trading partners
Attract more suppliers to do business with
Minimize dependence on sole and single source vendors
Develop negotiation techniques focusing on your advantage

slides.title: One of the biggest issues identified by WorldCC research is the failure of both buyers and suppliers to grasp the issue of:

interactions.lmstext: One of the biggest issues identified by WorldCC research is the failure of both buyers and suppliers to grasp the issue of:

choices.lmstext: Drafting quality contracts that support delivery of a long term relationship
Accurately allocating appropriate levels of liability and risk management
The desired business outcomes and scope of requirements
Complexity caused by overly long contracts

slides.title: Considering the result of WorldCC research, if we want to get better economic value from contracts, which types of terms should we focus our attention on?

interactions.lmstext: Considering the result of WorldCC research, if we want to get better economic value from contracts, which types of terms should we focus our attention on?

choices.lmstext: Risk allocation, liabilities, indemnities
Scope and goals, dealing with change, communicating between the parties
Pricing, milestones, schedules
Benchmarking, pricing, price variation clauses

slides.title: In considering an appropriate SRM mission statement, which of these would be the most appropriate?

interactions.lmstext: In considering an appropriate SRM mission statement, which of these would be the most appropriate?

choices.lmstext: Provide a coordinated communications conduit between the internal and external stakeholders to maximize competitive advantage
Provide a route to better supplier pricing through better sourcing and negotiation planning
Provide a coordinated communications conduit between internal stakeholders to maximize business performance
Provide the capability by which our organization will become the world leader in our area of expertise

slides.title: Which of the following would be the most appropriate vision statement to support a mission statement for SRM?

interactions.lmstext: Which of the following would be the most appropriate vision statement to support a mission statement for SRM?

choices.lmstext: Our internal stakeholders will develop improved business results by getting better control over the costs existing in our supply chain
Our external stakeholders will be able to communicate more easily with us, so that there is less confused messaging between the organizations
Our internal and external stakeholders will develop improved relationships that will lead to a long term commitment to creating win-win scenarios where we share in both the good and the bad times
SRM will drive the vision by which our organization will become the guiding light to which all our competitors will aspire

slides.title: The value of an SRM function to an organization is that it can:\n1) Directly create income\n2) Indirectly create income

interactions.lmstext: The value of an SRM function to an organization is that it can:\n1) Directly create income\n2) Indirectly create income

choices.lmstext: Only 1 is true
Only 2 is true
Both 1 & 2 are true
Neither 1 or 2 is true

slides.title: Which of the following skills should an SRM manager have?

interactions.lmstext: Which of the following skills should an SRM manager have?

choices.lmstext: intolerance
Adaptability
Diversity
Inflexibility

slides.title: Should the exit transition plan with a strategic supplier be included in a contract schedule?

interactions.lmstext: Should the exit transition plan with a strategic supplier be included in a contract schedule?

choices.lmstext: Absolutely always
No, never
It depends
Only for international contracts

slides.title: So long as the contract contains a right of termination, there are no significant factors for the customer to consider since all costs for termination will rest on the supplier:

interactions.lmstext: So long as the contract contains a right of termination, there are no significant factors for the customer to consider since all costs for termination will rest on the supplier:

choices.lmstext: Yes, the supplier always bears the full cost of exit
No, exit costs usually sit with both parties
Yes, exit costs are fixed as part of the initial contract price
No, the customer must bear the full cost of exit

slides.title: Is it always a bad idea to consider ways to sustain a relationship when substantially all the elements of contract are being terminated?

interactions.lmstext: Is it always a bad idea to consider ways to sustain a relationship when substantially all the elements of contract are being terminated?

choices.lmstext: No, it may make good business sense to
Yes, it implies weakness
Yes, the supplier will not be motivated to perform
No, because it will damage friendships

slides.title: Within organizations, the culture of different teams can be largely set by:

interactions.lmstext: Within organizations, the culture of different teams can be largely set by:

choices.lmstext: Issuing clear instructions to the teams on the way we wish them to act
The leaders of the teams, largely by the way those leaders act on a daily basis (or fail to act)
Governance processes and clear direction in procedures
Team building
